thread.title: New York’s One-Bedroom Rents Drop
thread.title_full: New York’s One-Bedroom Rents Drop - The New York Times

author: Michael Kolomatsky
title: New York’s One-Bedroom Rents Drop
text:
In December 2016, median rents for one-bedroom apartments decreased in eight of the 10 most expensive American markets, compared with the same month a year earlier, according to a report published by the rental information website Zumper.com .
The only cities in the top 10 that didn’t have an annual drop were Seattle and Los Angeles .
One-Bedroom Rent Changes Over One Year
Ten Most Expensive U.S. Markets
San Francisco
–4% to $3,350
New York
–9.1% to $2,980
Boston
–5.9% to $2,250
San Jose, Calif.
–1.4% to $2,170
Oakland, Calif.
–5.4% to $2,090
Washington, D.C.
–5.6% to $2,030
Los Angeles
+3.6% to $1,990
Chicago
–5.6% to $1,860
Miami
–1.1% to $1,800
Seattle
+8.5% to $1,790

Source: Zumper.com FEB. 17, 2017
By The New York Times The decrease in New York City was by far the biggest, at 9.1 percent. That’s good news for the city’s renters, but it’s relative: New York is still the second-most-expensive place in the country to rent an apartment, topped only by San Francisco. And while the median one-bedroom rent dropped below the $3,000 mark — to $2,980 — the national median is just $1,139.
